article.title: Anaconda
article.paragraph: aboutsnakesUse dmy datesJune 2013File:01-COBRA-SUCURI-3M-WAGNER-MEIER MG 2458.JPGthumbrightGreen anacondaAnanacondais a largesnakefound in tropicalSouth America. Although the name applies to a group of snakes, it is often used to refer only to one species in particular, the common or green anaconda,Eunectes murinus, which is the largest snake in the world by weight, and the second longest.

list.listitem: Any member of the genusEunectes, a group of large, aquatic snakes found in South AmericaEunectes murinus, the green anaconda, the largest species, is found east of the Andes in Colombia, Venezuela, the Guianas, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, Brazil andTrinidad and Tobago.Eunectes notaeus, the yellow anaconda, a small species, is found in eastern Bolivia, southern Brazil, Paraguay and northeastern Argentina.Eunectes deschauenseei, the darkly-spotted anaconda, is a rare species found in northeastern Brazil and coastal French Guiana.Eunectes beniensis, the Bolivian anaconda, the most recently defined species, is found in the Departments of Beni and Pando inBolivia.
Thegiant anacondais a mythical snake of enormous proportions said to be found in South America.

Any large snake that "constricts" its prey (seeConstriction), if applied loosely, was called anaconda,Oxford. 1991. The Compact Oxford English Dictionary. Second Edition. Clarendon Press, Oxford. ISBN 0-19-861258-3.though this usage is now archaic.

article.heading: Etymology
article.paragraph: The South American namesanacauchoaandanacaonawere suggested in an account byPeter Martyr d'Anghierabut the idea of a South American origin was questioned byHenry Walter Bateswho, in his travels in South America, failed to find any similar name in use. The word anaconda is derived from the name of a snake from Ceylon (Sri Lanka) thatJohn Raydescribed in Latin in hisSynopsis Methodica Animalium(1693) asserpens indicus bubalinus anacandaia zeylonibus, ides bubalorum aliorumque jumentorum membra conterens.cite bookhttp://archive.org/stream/synopsismethodic00rayj#page/332/mode/1up3321693Ray, JohnSynopsis methodica animalium quadrupedum et serpentini generisImpensis S. Smith & B. WalfordLondonRay used a catalogue of snakes from the Leyden museum supplied by Dr.Tancred Robinson, but the description of its habit was based onAndreas Cleyerwho in 1684 described a gigantic snake that crushed large animals by coiling and crushing their bones.cite bookCharlesOwen1742An essay towards a natural history of serpents114http://archive.org/stream/essaytowardsnat00owen#page/114/mode/2up/Henry Yulein hisHobson-Jobsonnotes that the word became more popular due to a piece of fiction published in 1768 in the Scots Magazine by a certain R. Edwin. Edwin described atigerbeing crushed and killed by an anaconda when in fact tigers never occurred in Sri Lanka. Yule andFrank Wallnoted that the snake was in fact a python and suggested aTamil languageTamiloriginanai-kondrameaning elephant killer.Cite bookWallFrank1921Ophidia Taprobanica or the Snakes of Ceylon.Government PressCeylonhttp://archive.org/stream/ophidiataprobani00wall#page/48/mode/1up/search/48ASinhala languageSinhaleseorigin was also suggested by Donald Ferguson who pointed out that the wordHenakandaya(henalightning/large andkandastem/trunk) was used in Sri Lanka for the small whip snake (Ahaetulla pulverulenta)cite journalSpolia Zeylanica19041http://archive.org/stream/spoliazeylanica01nati#page/84/mode/1up/Some rare snakes of Ceylon81–89Willey, Aand somehow got misapplied to the python before myths were created.cite journalNotes and Queries121897Ferguson, Donald123–124The derivation of "Anaconda"http://archive.org/stream/s8notesqueries12londuoft#page/122/mode/1upcite bookA concise etymological dictionary of the English LanguageSkeatWalter W.Oxford University Press188216http://archive.org/stream/conciseetymologi00skea#page/16/mode/1upcite bookhttp://archive.org/stream/hobsonjobsonagl02croogoog#page/n75/mode/1up24–25Hobson-Jobson.YuleHenryA.C.BurnellJohn MurrayLondon1903
The name commonly used for the anaconda in Brazil issucuri,sucurijuorsucuriuba.cite webDicionário online de português: sucurijuhttp://www.dicio.com.br/sucuriju/19 February 2014
